nodes.bodyText:
Just curious if it's good to expose Netty proxy handler directly to the user.
Especially if we start to support Forward Proxy, we may need to add one more netty handler in the middle. Then the proxy handler is not suitable for that case. It's better to provide proxy setting from armeria?
JFYI my investigation kojilin@6cbd1e4#diff-fd04617458eb8556240b7e1a48959f8bR349

Good point.   Was also thinking about this yesterday for a while.
Each proxy will require different parameters (connectionTimeout, user, password, etc.), so the choice was either to expose netty apis, or to create a wrapper.
I'm still unsure about this though.   (I haven't really thought about Forward Proxy..)
I'll take a look at your draft later 🙏 🙇 👍

we may need to add one more netty handler in the middle

Agreed.  I have added ssl support to CONNECT to support this claim.
Thanks for the investigation by the way, it actually helped a lot.  I actually couldn't use mock-server like you did since I wanted some negative test cases, but I had a fun day looking through the mock-server code 👍
Also, I am getting the feeling support for regular forward proxy will be trickier.. (especially with HTTP2). I am working on a POC, so I'll maybe upload a PR separately if I get it sorted out.
Maybe 1 more HttpProxyHandler for CONNECT?
I think HttpProxyHandler should be added after ssl is applied (at least that's what the netty examples were doing 🤔 )

You mean between client and proxy using https? If we use HttpProxyHandler directly, we may support nomral HTTP CONNECT one I think.
--
Also can you tell me the link, just curious about which example.

https://github.com/netty/netty/blob/5c458c9a98d4d3d0345e58495e017175156d624f/handler-proxy/src/test/java/io/netty/handler/proxy/ProxyHandlerTest.java#L360
Didn't really take a thorough look though.. (I didn't really have time to look at HttpProxyHandler internals yet)

So it looks like 2 cases.
If we want to provide https proxy, I think as you said we need to put before HttpProxyHandler.
But there is another https between client and the real server?

Ah,   I see.  You're right in that there are 2 cases.
This may complicate the api a bit (we may need to add another ssl handler if we want to support Http[s]ProxyHandler 🤔 )
proxy() for consistency
configureProxy ?
"{} Ignoring unknown proxy type: {}", ch, proxy.proxyType() ?

final
Probably ProxyConfig is better?
Please implement toString() for this class and its subclasses.

nodes.bodyText: How about just splitting into username() and password()?

Actually, as you may know HttpProxyHandler requires both username, password are either null or non-null.
If we decide to split this, I can add validation logic to the build method, but I felt this style of API would communicate this restraint to the user better. Let me know what you think 😉
OK, then how about renaming to credential()?
if connect timeout is optional, we can remove the factory methods with connectTimeoutMillis and add connectTimeout(Duration) and connectTimeoutMillis(long) to the builder class.
Decided to get rid of proxy specific connectTimeoutMillis  and use ClientFactory.connectTimeoutMillis.
Make all non-builder classes purely immutable.
This seems unused but I guess you have a plan. 😉

nodes.bodyText:
start with builder()

I think It might be hard to express that only one of the proxy protocols can be selected with this API. As @trustin suggested, I think I would need a method like builderForSocks4 to go with this route .

give up builder API and just add various factory methods

I initially tried to avoid this bc I don't like nullable parameters, but I do feel like this pattern may be slightly overkill.
Decided to go with factory methods to save users from typing the extra build() 😉

+     */

+        return NOOP_PROXY_CONFIG;

nodes.bodyText: These fields are non-existent when disabled or when we add a config with different authentication mechanism such as SASL. Could you push them down to the subtypes and make this class an interface?

Actually I made ProxyConfig a class with a default visibility constructor to prevent library users from extending on their own. Let me know if you have a better idea (or if an interface is just fine since we are leaving warning logs for unknown ProxyConfig types anyways)
Ah, OK, then.
Missing final

nodes.bodyText: Returns the ...
Returns whether TLS is enabled
Returns the ...
Please move down.
Sorry, I always seem to forget this :P
No worries. We love you, fellow contributor. ❤️
Perhaps better making username non-null, given that we have the version that does not require username?
Ditto - username and password could be non-null.
Ditto - username and password could be non-null.
Could just add isDisabled method to ProxyConfig and returns true in DisabledProxyConfig.
Or an enum, like ProxyType? E.g. ProxyType.SOCKS5
Ah that's better. 😄

So the reason I removed enum ProxyType previously was basically because I didn't like how when the end-user types Proxy..., intellij autocomplete would show ProxyType, but it doesn't really serve any purpose to the end-user.
For us, I definitely agree the switch case statement looks a lot cleaner 😄, so i guess this is a trade-off.
We can 1) keep as-is 2) revert back (I intentionally created a separate commit) 3)  move all proxy related classes to com.linecorp.armeria.client and keep ProxyType package private.
Let me know what you guys think 🙇
SGTM :-)

For me, I like the current code because I think it's much readable. 😉
Also, I don't think we don't have to move the package because:

It doesn't harm to show one more class which starts with Proxy... because the IntelliJ shows them(there are so many classes already but we can know which one is from Armeria) with the package and I think the name, which is ProxyType, is clear to understand.
netty-handler-proxy could be declared at implementation configuration? I know we need to move some other netty modules from api to implementation, but I thought this may be a good baby step.
Could remove Contains and related from all ProxyConfig classes, i.e. CONNECT proxy configuration.

+package com.linecorp.armeria.client.proxy;
+
+import static com.linecorp.armeria.client.proxy.DisabledProxyConfig.DISABLED_PROXY_CONFIG;
+import static java.util.Objects.requireNonNull;
+
+import java.net.InetSocketAddress;
+
+import javax.annotation.Nullable;
+
+import com.linecorp.armeria.client.ClientFactory;
+
+/**
+ * Base configuration for proxy settings used by {@link ClientFactory}.
+ */
+public abstract class ProxyConfig {
+
+    /**
+     * Creates a {@code ProxyConfig} configuration for SOCKS4 protocol.
+     *
+     * @param proxyAddress The proxy address.
+     */
+    public static Socks4ProxyConfig socks4(InetSocketAddress proxyAddress) {
+        return new Socks4ProxyConfig(requireNonNull(proxyAddress, "proxyAddress"), null);
+    }
+
+    /**
+     * Creates a {@code ProxyConfig} configuration for SOCKS4 protocol.
+     *
+     * @param proxyAddress The proxy address.
+     * @param username The username.
+     */
+    public static Socks4ProxyConfig socks4(InetSocketAddress proxyAddress, String username) {
+        return new Socks4ProxyConfig(requireNonNull(proxyAddress, "proxyAddress"),
+                                     requireNonNull(username, "username"));
+    }
+
+    /**
+     * Creates a {@code ProxyConfig} configuration for SOCKS5 protocol.
+     *
+     * @param proxyAddress The proxy address.
+     */
+    public static Socks5ProxyConfig socks5(InetSocketAddress proxyAddress) {
+        return new Socks5ProxyConfig(requireNonNull(proxyAddress, "proxyAddress"), null, null);
+    }
+
+    /**
+     * Creates a {@code ProxyConfig} configuration for SOCKS5 protocol.
+     *
+     * @param proxyAddress The proxy address.
+     * @param username The username.
+     * @param password The password.
+     */
+    public static Socks5ProxyConfig socks5(
+            InetSocketAddress proxyAddress, String username, String password) {
+        return new Socks5ProxyConfig(
+                requireNonNull(proxyAddress, "proxyAddress"), requireNonNull(username, "username"),
+                requireNonNull(password, "password"));
+    }
+
+    /**
+     * Creates a {@code ProxyConfig} configuration for CONNECT protocol.
+     *
+     * @param proxyAddress The proxy address.
+     */
+    public static ConnectProxyConfig connect(InetSocketAddress proxyAddress) {
+        return new ConnectProxyConfig(requireNonNull(proxyAddress, "proxyAddress"), null, null, false);
+    }
+
+    /**
+     * Creates a {@code ProxyConfig} configuration for CONNECT protocol.
+     *
+     * @param proxyAddress The proxy address.
+     * @param useTls Whether to use TLS to connect to the proxy.
+     */
+    public static ConnectProxyConfig connect(
+            InetSocketAddress proxyAddress, boolean useTls) {
+        return new ConnectProxyConfig(
+                requireNonNull(proxyAddress, "proxyAddress"), null, null, useTls);
+    }
+
+    /**
+     * Creates a {@code ProxyConfig} configuration for CONNECT protocol.
+     *
+     * @param proxyAddress The proxy address.
+     * @param username The username.
+     * @param password The password.
+     * @param useTls Whether to use TLS to connect to the proxy.
+     */
+    public static ConnectProxyConfig connect(
+            InetSocketAddress proxyAddress, String username, String password, boolean useTls) {
+        return new ConnectProxyConfig(
+                requireNonNull(proxyAddress, "proxyAddress"), requireNonNull(username, "username"),
+                requireNonNull(password, "password"), useTls);
+    }
+
+    /**
+     * Returns a {@code ProxyConfig} which signifies that proxy is disabled.
+     */
+    public static ProxyConfig disabled() {
+        return DISABLED_PROXY_CONFIG;
+    }
+
+    @Nullable
+    static String maskedStr(@Nullable String value) {
+        return value == null ? null : "****";

nodes.bodyText: How about renaming to ProxyConfig.direct() and DirectProxyConfig, given that JDK uses DIRECT?
How about reviving this and using omitNullValues() for ToStringHelper? Showing **** for a non-existent password may give a user a misconception that authentication is enabled.
We could still return **** when username is not null, although it's not very likely in our current code base.
nit: proxyConfig.proxyType() ?
